Video Connectors

HDMI, DisplayPort, DVI, VGA, and Thunderbolt video connections.

2 connector types documented

DisplayPort

DisplayPort

VESA

Max Speed

77.4 Gbps

Max Power

1.65W

Connector

20 pins, 16.1×4.76mm

Common Uses

Computer monitors Graphics cards Laptops (business/professional) +4 more

⚠️ DisplayPort and Mini DisplayPort have identical capabilities - only the connector size differs

DisplayPort is technically superior to HDMI for computer use, with higher bandwidth, daisy-chaining support, and royalty-free licensing. However, HDMI dominates consumer electronics. DisplayPort Alt Mode over USB-C is increasingly common, making USB-C the de facto DisplayPort connector on modern laptops. DisplayPort 2.1 with UHBR 20 mode offers nearly 4x the bandwidth of HDMI 2.1.

HDMI

High-Definition Multimedia Interface

HDMI Forum

Max Speed

48 Gbps

Max Power

0.275W

Connector

19 pins, 13.9×4.45mm

Common Uses

TVs Monitors Gaming consoles (PS5, Xbox Series X) +6 more

⚠️ HDMI 2.1 ports may not support all 2.1 features - manufacturers can pick and choose which features to implement

HDMI has been the dominant consumer A/V connector since the mid-2000s. The transition to HDMI 2.1 has been confusing because manufacturers can implement subsets of features. When buying a TV or monitor for gaming, verify specific feature support (VRR, ALLM, 4K@120Hz) rather than just checking for 'HDMI 2.1' branding.

About Video Connectors

Video connectors have evolved significantly with increasing resolution and refresh rate demands. Understanding bandwidth requirements is key to choosing the right cable.

Common Standards

  • HDMI 2.1 - 48 Gbps, 4K@120Hz, 8K@60Hz
  • DisplayPort 2.1 - 80 Gbps, 16K support
  • Thunderbolt 4 - 40 Gbps, daisy-chaining
  • DVI/VGA - Legacy, limited resolution

Bandwidth Requirements

  • 1080p@60Hz: ~3.2 Gbps
  • 4K@60Hz: ~12.5 Gbps
  • 4K@120Hz: ~25 Gbps
  • 8K@60Hz: ~50 Gbps
